utterances: Well, as soon as you decide what you'd like to say, send us a message.
Go to our Web site, npr.org, and click on ""Contact Us"" at the top of the page.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
There are conflicting reports about whether the police and barriers around the home of Pakistan's former prime minister are actually being removed.
But the acting deputy commissioner of Islamabad says an order for Benazir Bhutto's detention has been withdrawn.
The state of emergency ordered by General Pervez Musharraf has now been in place for nearly a week.
And police placed Bhutto under house arrest this morning, preventing her from attending a rally.
That prompted a new White House call for an early end to the state of emergency and the release of political party members and peaceful protesters.
NPR's Philip Reeves is in Islamabad.
He has this report and analysis of today's events.
A squad of riot police tramps up as if ready for battle.
They've come here in case there's trouble with people like thisâ€¦
(Soundbite of protesters chanting)
A group of Bhutto's party activists.
They are outside Bhutto's residence.
Bhutto is inside separated from us by razor wire, concrete barriers and lots of police.
(Soundbite of people clashing)
Every now and then, intelligence agents in plain clothes pounce on one of her supporters and whisk them away.
At face value, this looks like a clear-cut confrontation - a famous woman politician versus a military dictator.
But when you look more closely, the picture is a little more complicated.
It's like arm wrestling.
Pakistan is on the verge of destabilization.
On one side of the table, you have Musharraf, president and army chief.
The general has the support of the U.S., which regards him as indispensable in the war on Islamist militancy.
He's been in power for eight years and he wants to stay there.
But he's unpopular and his opponents claim his recent reelection was illegal.
Musharraf was so worried that Pakistan's Supreme Court would agree with them that he imposed emergency rule.
This is a battle for democracy.
On the other side of the table, you have another formidable combatant - Benazir Bhutto, former prime minister.
Bhutto also has the support of the U.S.
She also wants Musharraf to stay as president, but she and Washington are trying to push Musharraf into a transition from military to civilian rule.
That means he must resign as army chief and hold parliamentary elections.
Bhutto hopes this will mean she'll get another shot at being prime minister.
And Washington hopes that means they keep their man, Musharraf, and that the two of them form a secular front against the Islamists.
The two have been negotiating for months, now they're using different tactics to force each other's arms.
Bhutto says it's all Musharraf's fault.
And I'm very disappointed that though there was a peaceful way, he chose the nonpolitical path.
That's Bhutto speaking today outside her residence.
She was on one side of the barbwire, the camera crews and scores of riot police were on the other.
We are calling for the revival of our constitution and respect for our tradition.
We are calling for General Musharraf to keep his commitment and resign as chief of army (unintelligible).
Musharraf locked up Bhutto in her house today because she decided to call a rally of her supporters in the nearby city of Rawalpindi.
This was her way of pressuring Musharraf and his fellow generals to agree to her demands.
But under emergency rule, demonstrations are banned.
Thousands of police and troops were deployed in Rawalpindi, sealing off the rally ground.
So the regime has a choice, either paralysis or not putting obstacles in our path.
Bhutto, a master of publicity, was still able to take center stage and she made the most of it.
The government eventually tried to counterattack by saying it was worried her mass rally would be attacked by a suicide bomber.
But by the time they came out with that argument, Bhutto had already stolen the show.
For the players themselves, that's what it is - a show, political theatre created to pressure one another.

But there's nothing entertaining about the crisis for thousands of Pakistanis out in the provincial towns and cities, away from the cameras, who've been arrested and beaten simply for demanding real democracy and rule of law.
Philip Reeves, NPR News, Islamabad.
No matter what happens with the vote in the Senate, research on stem-cells in general and embryonic stem-cells in particular continues to expand both here and abroad.
Joining us to talk about this burgeoning field is NPR science correspondent Joe Palca.
And Joe, remind us, please, why it is that scientists see such tremendous potential in embryonic stem cells.
The government is reluctant to admit that there might be a negative effect on Iran's overall economy.
But Haida Purian(ph), editor-in-chief of Iran Economics magazine says this rationing is bound to decrease Iran's rate of economic growth.
We are already seeing some negative effect on transportation, on tourism.
On Caspian Sea, in the resort areas usually at the summer it's very full of people, now, it's been reported that few people travel to this area.
The government could have chosen to reduce gasoline consumption by gradually raising prices.
But apparently, the political risks of that were considered far worst than the impact of rationing.
Mike Shuster, NPR News, Tehran.
As more countries commit troops to the peacekeeping mission in southern Lebanon, Israeli forces are expected to start pulling back.
Israeli security officials say that could happen in the next few weeks if deployments go according to plan.
For civilians on both sides of the border, the cleanup after the fighting goes on as people try to resume a more normal life.
NPR's Michael Sullivan sent this report from the Israeli town of Kiryat Shimona.
School started all over Israel yesterday, including in and around Kiryat Shimona, one of the places hardest hit by Hezbollah's Katyushas during the war.
(Soundbite of children)
Children greeted each other with squeals, smiles and hugs after spending much of the summer and the war in underground shelters or with friends or relatives farther south.
The Aleg Avas(ph) School is just outside Kiryat Shimona and parents dropping off children there don't seem too worried about bringing the children back so soon after the war.
Adit(ph) brought her seven-year-old daughter from nearby Mechola (ph).
One of the best things to recover from the war for the kids is to be together.
This is like to be sick and to recover.
To be together and to be in school and to have a scheduled day.
That's the normalizer.
That's the best.
The principal here, Tol Rabinski(ph), says there are very few no-shows.
Four hundred children are registered here, she says, and only three families have decided not to return and to move elsewhere, somewhere presumably safe.
(Speaking foreign language)
Rabinski says teachers will be extra vigilant this week, looking for signs of trauma or other emotional problems triggered by the war.
Today, she says, they'll also get reacquainted with the school's bomb shelter so they are prepared for the next time.
Almost everyone here seems to believe there will be a next time.
(Soundbite of music)
Kiryat Shimona's biggest mall was largely deserted during the war except for the fitness club in the basement that was used as a bomb shelter.
Today the mall is crowded, with summer sales in full swing at several clothing shops and jewelry stores.
(Soundbite of cash register)
Upstairs the food court is busy too, filled with young people including soldiers in uniform ordering schwarmas and slices of pizza.
The pizza stand's manager, Ron, says business now is the same as it was before the war.
And it didn't take long to get that way either, he says, after the cease-fire took effect.
(Pizza Stand Manager, Kiryat Shimona): About two days.
The first two days was quite calm but after two days, everything back to normal.
People started ordering pizza like no tomorrow.

People living here have lived through occasional and not so occasional rocket attacks for decades but nothing like what happened this summer, with hundreds of homes and businesses damaged or destroyed.
Now residents here are moving quickly to repair the damage.
(Soundbite of construction noise)
Near the center of the city workers are busy reframing and repainting several shops damaged by rockets that fell in early August.
Sion Levy's(ph) butcher shop took a direct hit.
Three days later, he says, he started rebuilding, not waiting for the war to end.
(Through Translator) We need to live and we need to work.
The three of us here working are supporting three families.
We can't just sit and wait for more Katyushas to fall.
We've been working 14 and 15 hour days to get this place back and running because the holidays are coming and we want the store back to normal.
And in another two or three days, it will be.
The government, Levy says, is paying for most but not all of the reconstruction.
Many Israelis have been sharply critical of the government for its handling, some say mishandling, of the war, which some say ended in a draw at best, if not a defeat.
Levy isn't among those critics and in fact he says things have turned out far better than he'd expected.
